commit_message:
Add privileged add, replace and delete route

This change introduces possibility to use pyroute2 within
privileged part of ip_lib to add, replace and delete
routes.

Related-bug: #1492714
Change-Id: I357a75c0447e931f495ab4c6d32d9cf537047a53
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/77/585177/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @privileged.default.entrypoint def add_route(namespace, **kwargs): """Add route. :param namespace: The name of the namespace where to add route """ with _get_iproute(namespace) as ip: ip.route('add', **kwargs) @privileged.default.entrypoint def replace_route(namespace, **kwargs): """Replace route. If route does not exist it will add new route. :param namespace: The name of the namespace where to replace route """ with _get_iproute(namespace) as ip: ip.route('replace', **kwargs) @privileged.default.entrypoint def delete_route(namespace, **kwargs): """Delete route. :param namespace: The name of the namespace where to delete route """ with _get_iproute(namespace) as ip: ip.route('del', **kwargs)

subject: Fix rebinding of "binding_failed" ports on startup
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-09 12:53:00.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/rpc.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a28093e75e248fb36ac69ca08358fd14dfe21ebf', 'message': 'Fix rebinding of "binding_failed" ports on startup

Since the switch to "CacheBackedPluginApi" the ovs-agent didn't try to
rebind ports at startup that were in the "binding_failed" state. This is
because the rebinding was triggered as part of the old implementation of
"get_device_details()" on the server side.

This commit changes the "CacheBackedPluginApi.get_device_details()" call
to fall back to the older implementation when encountering affected Ports.

Change-Id: Id453d85f392320ea852496c4a1c800558aa52dc8
Closes-bug: #1780453
'}]
commit_message:
Fix rebinding of "binding_failed" ports on startup

Since the switch to "CacheBackedPluginApi" the ovs-agent didn't try to
rebind ports at startup that were in the "binding_failed" state. This is
because the rebinding was triggered as part of the old implementation of
"get_device_details()" on the server side.

This commit changes the "CacheBackedPluginApi.get_device_details()" call
to fall back to the older implementation when encountering affected Ports.

Change-Id: Id453d85f392320ea852496c4a1c800558aa52dc8
Closes-bug: #1780453
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/01/590301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return super(CacheBackedPluginApi, self).get_device_details( context, device, agent_id, host )

subject: ovs: survive errors when recovering from ovs restart
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-04-12 21:38:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c19bf28d2414fa9bb63ea1b45288554c1423a73f', 'message': "ovs: survive errors when recovering from ovs restart

If ovs was restarted, and an error happens when resetting bridges /
tunnels / flows, the agent crashes and exits. To avoid that, we
make the agent catch all errors and gracefully ignore them (after
logging details), in hope that the next iteration will be more
successful.

Since we set up canary flows before the rest of _handle_ovs_restart
body, it's possible to receive an error after the flows are set on
bridges. In this case, the next iteration will return OVS_NORMAL from
check_canary_table(). We should handle this situation by forcing full
recovery after OVS restart. This is achieved by introducing the
``recover_needed`` boolean flag that serves as a sticky indication that
an OVS restart happened in the past that we haven't fully recovered
from.

Change-Id: I82597d731bcba38a67f29ba953ee3e14fd532020
Related-Bug: #1731494

commit_message:
ovs: survive errors when recovering from ovs restart

If ovs was restarted, and an error happens when resetting bridges /
tunnels / flows, the agent crashes and exits. To avoid that, we
make the agent catch all errors and gracefully ignore them (after
logging details), in hope that the next iteration will be more
successful.

Since we set up canary flows before the rest of _handle_ovs_restart
body, it's possible to receive an error after the flows are set on
bridges. In this case, the next iteration will return OVS_NORMAL from
check_canary_table(). We should handle this situation by forcing full
recovery after OVS restart. This is achieved by introducing the
``recover_needed`` boolean flag that serves as a sticky indication that
an OVS restart happened in the past that we haven't fully recovered
from.

Change-Id: I82597d731bcba38a67f29ba953ee3e14fd532020
Related-Bug: #1731494

added_lines: def test_rpc_loop_survives_error_in__handle_ovs_restart(self): with mock.patch.object(self.agent, '_handle_ovs_restart', side_effect=Exception('borked')),\ mock.patch.object(self.agent, '_check_and_handle_signal', side_effect=[True, False]): self.agent.rpc_loop(polling_manager=mock.Mock()) def test_rpc_loop_recovers_until_success(self): '''Test that after OVS restart the agent will trigger recovering until it's successfully completed. commit_message:
Stop handling 'cell_name' field on Instance.save()

Nothing should be setting these anymore so we can removed it.

Part of blueprint remove-cells-v1

Change-Id: I97d5269b2837c996d294baabb1395e4d90cad070
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: Avoid get_object for small queries
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-22 10:12:55.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/db/extradhcpopt_db.py', 'neutron/db/securitygroups_db.py', 'neutron/db/ipam_backend_mixin.py', 'neutron/db/l3_hamode_db.py', 'neutron/db/address_scope_db.py', 'neutron/db/l3_dvr_db.py', 'neutron/db/portsecurity_db_common.py', 'neutron/db/db_base_plugin_v2.py', 'neutron/db/agentschedulers_db.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/d1eef59d21dcb8f17ae86e746732f4b118333511', 'message': 'Avoid get_object for small queries

We use neutron objects for
1) RPC between neutron components
2) passing them between functions across modules
3) converting the DB columns to dict and serialize

But for small queries which need only few columns from tables
(without joining other tables), directly querying the databse
will improve the performance.

Co-Authored-By: Joe Talerico <jtaleric@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7a0316d42b952b9be01c8b7e7db8177d899b8394
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid get_object for small queries

We use neutron objects for
1) RPC between neutron components
2) passing them between functions across modules
3) converting the DB columns to dict and serialize

But for small queries which need only few columns from tables
(without joining other tables), directly querying the databse
will improve the performance.

Co-Authored-By: Joe Talerico <jtaleric@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I7a0316d42b952b9be01c8b7e7db8177d899b8394

added_lines: from neutron.objects import port as port_obj ports = port_obj.Port.get_objects( context, network_id=net_data['id']) if ports: ports = port_obj.Port.get_objects( context, l3_models.Router.gw_port_id.in_([port.id for port in ports]))
deleted_lines: port = context.session.query(models_v2.Port).filter_by( network_id=net_data['id']).first() if port: ports = context.session.query(models_v2.Port.id).filter_by( l3_models.Router.gw_port_id.in_(ports))

subject: DNM: Test commit to verify fs53 triggers
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-09-14 14:43:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/699dc62add1232b53e3f3fcaa9296f97df9d1a7c', 'message': 'DNM: Test commit to verify fs53 triggers

commit_message:
Remove the loadbalancer policy rules

These policy rules are used by neutron lbaas which has been
splited out from neutron. In addition, the neutron-lbaas is
deprecated in flavor of octavia, but octavia doesn't use these
rules. This commit removes these rules from sample policy files.

Change-Id: I000e854f8e86a8cccfdc437b8fe0ee689e403229

commit_message:
Remove deprecated option split_branches from migration CLI

The 'split_branches' option in the migration CLI was deprecated in
Newton and scheduled for removal in Ocata.  This finally dispenses with
it.

Change-Id: I2f084a2fa7876bfd298429d9fa0784c269cb7f21

commit_message:
add vmware-nsx non voting py35 job

As per our PTG discussion, networking projects can add non-voting jobs
to neutron check queue as a means to smoke-screen failures introduced by
neutron patches.

This patch adds a non-voting job that runs vmware-nsx UTs with neutron
based on what the requirements repo does [2].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-September/135032.html
[2] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/master/.zuul.d/cross-jobs.yaml

Change-Id: I4641a4e540635590c363a997cf8d20a02b7c24e0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/61/605861/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - neutron-openstack-tox-py35-with-vmware-nsx - job: name: neutron-openstack-tox-py35-with-vmware-nsx parent: openstack-tox description: Run vmware-nsx UTs against neutron timeout: 8400 vars: tox_envlist: py3 required-projects: - openstack/vmware-nsx voting: false

commit_message:
Move retry_if_session_inactive to tag OVO

Move db_api.retry_if_session_inactive decorator from tag_plugin
update_tags method to tag OVO delete_objects and create methods as an
effort to move all dependencies to dp_api to OVO, see discussion here:
https://review.openstack.org/565773

Co-Authored-By: Hongbin Lu <hongbin.lu@huawei.com>

Change-Id: I28d6154fbe274c24b9d2cdc4df90f611a5b5650f
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

added_lines: import inspect # Note(lajoskatona): if f() has self or cls, give another chance # as that can have context_var_name, and we can check that in # wrapped later. f_args = inspect.getargspec(f) if not any(p in f_args.args for p in ['self', 'cls']): raise RuntimeError("Could not find position of var %s" % context_var_name) # Note(lajoskatona): check if f() has self or cls as first arg, # and check if that has context_var_name: elif hasattr(args[0], context_var_name): context = getattr(args[0], context_var_name)
deleted_lines: raise RuntimeError("Could not find position of var %s" % context_var_name)

commit_message:
Use OVO in neutron/ipam/subnet_alloc.py

Migrate to using Subnet and SubnetPool OVO objects in the IPAM subnet
allocation code.

This removes the test test_subnetpool_concurrent_allocation_exception
from the TestSubnetAllocation tests because that exception is no longer
generated in the objectified code path.

Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db
Change-Id: I0f0a3482a5a91881927cfe39fc40e042d6ac10cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/53/579053/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.objects import subnet as subnet_obj from neutron.objects import subnetpool as subnetpool_obj subnet_pool = subnetpool_obj.SubnetPool.get_objects(self._context, id=self._subnetpool['id']).pop() current_hash = subnet_pool.hash if subnet_pool else None subnet_pool.hash = uuidutils.generate_uuid() subnet_pool.update() subnets = subnet_obj.Subnet.get_objects(self._context, subnetpool_id=self._subnetpool['id']) return (x.cidr for x in subnets) allocations = subnet_obj.Subnet.get_objects(self._context, subnetpool_id=subnetpool_id, tenant_id=tenant_id) value = 0 for allocation in allocations: prefixlen = netaddr.IPNetwork(allocation.cidr).prefixlen value += self._num_quota_units_in_prefixlen(prefixlen, quota_unit) return value
deleted_lines: from neutron_lib import exceptions as lib_exc from oslo_db import exception as db_excfrom neutron.db import models_v2 with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(self._context): current_hash = ( self._context.session.query(models_v2.SubnetPool.hash) .filter_by(id=self._subnetpool['id']).scalar()) new_hash = uuidutils.generate_uuid() # NOTE(cbrandily): the update disallows 2 concurrent subnet allocation # to succeed: at most 1 transaction will succeed, others will be # rolled back and be caught in neutron.db.v2.base with db_api.context_manager.writer.using(self._context): query = ( self._context.session.query(models_v2.SubnetPool).filter_by( id=self._subnetpool['id'], hash=current_hash)) count = query.update({'hash': new_hash}) if not count: raise db_exc.RetryRequest(lib_exc.SubnetPoolInUse( subnet_pool_id=self._subnetpool['id'])) with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(self._context): query = self._context.session.query(models_v2.Subnet) subnets = query.filter_by(subnetpool_id=self._subnetpool['id']) return (x.cidr for x in subnets) with db_api.context_manager.reader.using(self._context): qry = self._context.session.query(models_v2.Subnet) allocations = qry.filter_by(subnetpool_id=subnetpool_id, tenant_id=tenant_id) value = 0 for allocation in allocations: prefixlen = netaddr.IPNetwork(allocation.cidr).prefixlen value += self._num_quota_units_in_prefixlen(prefixlen, quota_unit) return value

commit_message:
Floating IPs should not allocate IPv6 addresses

When there are both IPv4 and IPv6 subnets on the public
network, the port that a floating IP allocates there gets
assigned addresses from both subnets.

Allocating an IPv6 address should be avoided for
neutron floating ip if those plugins not support
associating IPv6 floating IPs to IPv4 fixed IPs.

Change-Id: I229ccf1483bf284f6c7f329980c8f391efd4fae9
Closes-Bug: #1752903

added_lines: def test_ipv6_subnet_with_canonical_addressing(self): res = self._create_network(fmt=self.fmt, name='net', admin_state_up=True) network = self.deserialize(self.fmt, res) cidr = 'fe80:0:0:0:0:0:0:1/64' gateway = 'fe80:0:0:0:0:0:0:1' pool = [{'start': 'fe80:0:0:0:0:0:0:2', 'end': 'fe80:0:0:0:0:0:0:12'}] subnet = self._make_subnet(self.fmt, network, gateway=gateway, subnetpool_id=None, cidr=cidr, ip_version=6, allocation_pools=pool, ipv6_ra_mode=constants.IPV6_SLAAC, ipv6_address_mode=constants.IPV6_SLAAC) self.assertEqual('fe80::1', subnet['subnet']['gateway_ip']) self.assertEqual('fe80::/64', subnet['subnet']['cidr']) self.assertEqual([{'start': 'fe80::2', 'end': 'fe80::12'}], subnet['subnet']['allocation_pools'])

This patch set fixes create_subnet:segment_id and
update_subnet:segment_id policies not getting enforced

commit_message:
Let Neutron enforce rule on create_subnet with segment_id [neutron part]

Neutron ignores rule in policy file [0], that allows non-admin users
to create subnets with segment_id.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/etc/policy.json#L19

Partial-Bug: 1784259

commit_message:
WIP: Give back http403 for get without permission

Operation show (GET /v2.0/resources/uuid) gives back exceptionto the user
if the user has no right (based on policy.json) to fetch the resource.
For list operation (GET v2.0/resources) on the contrary gives back an
empty list, without giving any kind of feedback to the user.
In case the list is empty because there is no resource which can be
visible by the user there should be an error message (http 403 for
example).

TODO:
* Tests (unit, functional?)

Change-Id: Ie4e7d847ca6d404c2b96929b5bab649ab10c3b46
Closes-Bug: #1789499

commit_message:
Speed-up ip neigh replace

With more than 1000 VMs in the same project, and 2 subnet in it (one for
ipv4 and one for ipv6), the l3 agent performs more than 4000 calls to ip
using rootwrap. This is a way too long, and can be replaced by some calls
to ip using the -batch option.

Closes-Bug: #1807396

Change-Id: Ic1c59a67aed6245b070640d7c63a8a96ac234279

added_lines: import tempfile import osfrom neutron.agent.common import utils def _update_arp_entry(self, ip, mac, subnet_id, operation, bfh=None): if bfh is not None or device.exists(): if operation == 'add': if bfh is None: device.neigh.add(ip, mac) else: os.write(batchfilehandle, "netns exec %s ip -%s neigh replace %s lladdr %s nud permanent dev %s\n" % (self.ns_name, netaddr.IPNetwork(ip).version, ip, mac, device)) batchfilehandle, batchfilename = tempfile.mkstemp() 'add', batchfilehandle=batchfilehandle) os.close(batchfilehandle) utils.execute( [ 'ip', '-batch', batchfilename ], run_as_root=True, log_fail_as_error=True) os.remove(batchfilename)

added_lines: from neutron_lib import constants as lib_constantsfrom neutron.common import constants as n_constsclass TestDistributedL3Agent(TestL3Agent): def setUp(self): # Create a 4 node configuraton with supported L3 agent modes # Create 2 DVR_SNAT nodes(for HA) # Create 1 DVR node # Create 1 DVR_NO_EXTERNAL node host_descriptions = [ environment.HostDescription( l3_agent=True, l3_agent_mode=lib_constants.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR_SNAT, dhcp_agent=True), environment.HostDescription( l3_agent=True, l3_agent_mode=lib_constants.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR_SNAT, dhcp_agent=True), environment.HostDescription( l3_agent=True, l3_agent_mode=lib_constants.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR), environment.HostDescription( l3_agent=True, l3_agent_mode=n_consts.L3_AGENT_MODE_DVR_NO_EXTERNAL)] env = environment.Environment( environment.EnvironmentDescription( network_type='vlan', l2_pop=False), host_descriptions) super(TestLegacyL3Agent, self).setUp(env) def _get_namespace(self, router_id): return namespaces.build_ns_name(namespaces.NS_PREFIX, router_id) def _get_fip_namespace(self, router_id): pass def _get_snat_namespace(self, router_id): pass def _assert_namespace_exists(self, ns_name): ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(ns_name) common_utils.wait_until_true(lambda: ip.netns.exists(ns_name)) def test_namespace_exists(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id) network = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, network['id'], '20.0.0.0/24', gateway_ip='20.0.0.1') self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) namespace = "%s@%s" % ( self._get_namespace(router['id']), self.environment.hosts[0].l3_agent.get_namespace_suffix(), ) self._assert_namespace_exists(namespace) def test_mtu_update(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id) network = self.safe_client.create_network(tenant_id) subnet = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, network['id'], '20.0.0.0/24', gateway_ip='20.0.0.1') self.safe_client.add_router_interface(router['id'], subnet['id']) namespace = "%s@%s" % ( self._get_namespace(router['id']), self.environment.hosts[0].l3_agent.get_namespace_suffix(), ) self._assert_namespace_exists(namespace) ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace) common_utils.wait_until_true(lambda: ip.get_devices()) devices = ip.get_devices() self.assertEqual(1, len(devices)) ri_dev = devices[0] mtu = ri_dev.link.mtu self.assertEqual(1500, mtu) mtu -= 1 network = self.safe_client.update_network(network['id'], mtu=mtu) common_utils.wait_until_true(lambda: ri_dev.link.mtu == mtu) def test_east_west_traffic(self): tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id) vm1 = self._create_net_subnet_and_vm( tenant_id, ['20.0.0.0/24', '2001:db8:aaaa::/64'], self.environment.hosts[0], router) vm2 = self._create_net_subnet_and_vm( tenant_id, ['21.0.0.0/24', '2001:db8:bbbb::/64'], self.environment.hosts[1], router) vm1.block_until_ping(vm2.ip) # Verify ping6 from vm2 to vm1 IPv6 Address vm2.block_until_ping(vm1.ipv6) def test_north_south_traffic(self): # This function creates an external network which is connected to # central_external_bridge and spawns an external_vm on it. # The external_vm is configured with the gateway_ip (both v4 & v6 # addresses) of external subnet. Later, it creates a tenant router, # a tenant network and two tenant subnets (v4 and v6). The tenant # router is associated with tenant network and external network to # provide north-south connectivity to the VMs. # We validate the following in this testcase. # 1. SNAT support: using ping from tenant VM to external_vm # 2. Floating IP support: using ping from external_vm to VM floating ip # 3. IPv6 ext connectivity: using ping6 from tenant vm to external_vm. tenant_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid() ext_net, ext_sub = self._create_external_network_and_subnet(tenant_id) external_vm = self.useFixture( machine_fixtures.FakeMachine( self.environment.central_external_bridge, common_utils.ip_to_cidr(ext_sub['gateway_ip'], 24))) # Create an IPv6 subnet in the external network v6network = self.useFixture( ip_network.ExclusiveIPNetwork( "2001:db8:1234::1", "2001:db8:1234::10", "64")).network ext_v6sub = self.safe_client.create_subnet( tenant_id, ext_net['id'], v6network) router = self.safe_client.create_router(tenant_id, external_network=ext_net['id']) # Configure the gateway_ip of external v6subnet on the external_vm. external_vm.ipv6_cidr = common_utils.ip_to_cidr( ext_v6sub['gateway_ip'], 64) # Configure an IPv6 downstream route to the v6Address of router gw port for fixed_ip in router['external_gateway_info']['external_fixed_ips']: if netaddr.IPNetwork(fixed_ip['ip_address']).version == 6: external_vm.set_default_gateway(fixed_ip['ip_address']) vm = self._create_net_subnet_and_vm( tenant_id, ['20.0.0.0/24', '2001:db8:aaaa::/64'], self.environment.hosts[1], router) # ping external vm to test snat vm.block_until_ping(external_vm.ip) fip = self.safe_client.create_floatingip( tenant_id, ext_net['id'], vm.ip, vm.neutron_port['id']) # ping floating ip from external vm external_vm.block_until_ping(fip['floating_ip_address']) # Verify VM is able to reach the router interface. vm.block_until_ping(vm.gateway_ipv6) # Verify north-south connectivity using ping6 to external_vm. vm.block_until_ping(external_vm.ipv6)

commit_message:
Support vlan transparent network for ml2 ovs driver

Now, ovs was supports QinQ, this patch can support vlan
transparent for openvswitch Ml2 driver, when tenant create
network which has 'vlan transprent' property.

This patch uses the already existing property 'vlan_transparent'
of network to indicates that corresponding ovs port needs to be
configure to QinQ mode.

Change-Id: Id1ac60795bbc793ba0777e6a096177d6c1725ad6
Closes-bug: #1604222
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/87/576687/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Added by lizhouzhou: set the arp related flows that match qinq @staticmethod def _arp_match_qinq(ofp, ofpp, port): return ofpp.OFPMatch(in_port=port, vlan_vid=(ofp.OFPVID_PRESENT, ofp.OFPVID_PRESENT), eth_type=ether_types.ETH_TYPE_ARP) # Added by lizhouzhou: set the flow of matched vlan id rule in br-int, # and the priority have to set to higher than normal flow def install_arp_match_qinq(self, port): (_dp, ofp, ofpp) = self._get_dp() match = self._arp_match_qinq(ofp, ofpp, port=port) self.install_goto(table_id=constants.LOCAL_SWITCHING, priority=11, match=match, dest_table_id=constants.TRANSIENT_TABLE) # Added by lizhouzhou: remove the arp related flows that match qinq def uninstall_arp_match_qinq(self, port): (_dp, ofp, ofpp) = self._get_dp() match = self._arp_match_qinq(ofp, ofpp, port=port) self.uninstall_flows(table_id=constants.LOCAL_SWITCHING, priority=11, match=match)

commit_message:
Regenerate process config files and parameters

For class ProcessManager, the parameters and config files are generated
by a callback function. This function generates config files and return
the command(with parameters). Sending HUP signal doesn't change
parameters, neither regenerate config files.

This patch is to ensure config files and parameters regenerated in
reload_cfg/restart.

Change-Id: I505676fe822b9cf33903a1de21e386568055478c
Closes-bug: #1809080

commit_message:
Fixes metering agent for DVR.

l3 agents on compute nodes get notifications now

commit_message:
Fix bug when floatingip and router bandwidth speed limit failure

When set mtu value to 64kb， the egress bandwidth limit of the VM
and the routing gateway will be invalid. I have tested it many
times. When set mtu value to 70kb, the bandwidth limit is normal.

For more information, you can read as follow:
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1785189/comments/5

Change-Id: Id17ad136914dad937c4a8fa5ac0959eb833a26d1
Closes-Bug: #1785189

as a result of duplicate start for PerodicWorker.

commit_message:
Graceful shutdown for neutron-server api worker

We need wait neutron-server api finish all it's requests
in wait function.

Closes-Bug: #1815871

commit_message:
Increase lease file buffering for dnsmasq lease reads

The default buffer of 4k is too small for larger envs, so
we frequently hit a race. Increase to 64k, which shouldn't
be too much of an overhead and still cover most cases.

Change-Id: I4d88c7e0d378bedb9aac2a42555d35295f447caf
Partial-Bug: #1788556

deleted_lines: with open(filename) as f: for l in f.readlines(): if host[1].startswith('set:'): continue with open(filename) as f: for l in f.readlines():

subject: Delete floating IPs on network turned internal
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-12-12 16:38:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/be927ae32f1343aef6f005b652b2d5004aee7961', 'message': "WIP Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

TODO tests

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-12-13 13:08:25.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/400daf9a384b9121045d53ff21724d27cf4816a9', 'message': "Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2019-01-30 10:08:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c4770966c1a94a2d1cdcea3504b2bf793ade7919', 'message': "Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/631515
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2019-02-18 09:29:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/a441490f5348fc813bef2cfe6d6eb0a953498edf', 'message': "Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440

commit_message:
Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

A router:external network can have floating IPs while an internal
network cannot. But so far the update of a network's router:external
attribute from True to False was allowed and the floating IPs kept
existing - creating an invalid state of objects.

The original discussion in the bug report suggested prohibiting the
network update in such conditions. But I discovered that a similar
operation (deleting an external net with floating IPs) was allowed
and the invalid state was resolved by automatically deleting the
corresponding floating IPs.

For the sake of consistent API behavior this change does the same for
the network update turning the net to internal.

As discussed in review a change like this in API behavior needs to be
discoverable by an API extension. Therefore this change also introduces
a shim extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

APIImpact: New extension: floatingip-autodelete-internal.

Change-Id: I2a39752bb4634c841d2d166c2bf03dac73188440
Closes-Bug: #1806032
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/637935

added_lines: from oslo_log import logLOG = log.getLogger(__name__) @registry.receives(resources.NETWORK, [events.AFTER_UPDATE]) def _after_network_update_handler( self, resource, event, trigger, context, network, original_network): # Turning a network from router:external to internal deletes the # corresponding floating IPs too. if (original_network[extnet_apidef.EXTERNAL] and not network[extnet_apidef.EXTERNAL]): LOG.debug( 'Deleting floating IPs of network updated' ' from external to internal: %s', network['id']) self._process_l3_delete(context, network['id'])

commit_message:
[WIP] Add native OVSDB implementation for polling monitor

TODO: remove prints and extra logs for debugging

This patch implements an OVS interface monitor based in the OVSDB
native implementation (OVSDB IDL, Open vSwitch Database Interface
Definition Language).

Closes-Bug: #1789592

Change-Id: I41651cafa21b90d3d07a2da882d35a762f29a727

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I160c141169d68fd9403604c68cecde0c70c463c3

commit_message:
the PeriodicWorker class init misssing desc argument

After this pr merged,https://review.openstack.org/#/c/637019/
we should add the default desc in PeriodicWorker class. Otherwise
some class based on the PeriodicWorker which does not set the
setproctitle =off in neutorn.conf will get an exception.
like below, where set_proctitle is None and there is no
setproctitle config

Closes-Bug:#1818765

Change-Id: Ib3e0273308b1c7824a1bd78a51b826e429d38fa4

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, check_func, interval, initial_delay): super(PeriodicWorker, self).__init__(worker_process_count=0)

subject: Integration of (Distributed) Port Binding OVO
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-14 08:16:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/332567de38f120ec2b480954c805e47561d374a7', 'message': 'Integration of (Distributed) Port Binding OVO

commit_message:
Integration of (Distributed) Port Binding OVO

This patch integrates Port Binding OVO in /plugins/ml2/db.py
and /plugins/ml2/plugin.py.

Change-Id: Ic70374aa75b151b7a06e640e397d8718450bc9c5
Co-Authored-By: Artur Korzeniewski <artur.korzeniewski@intel.com>
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
Set keepalived command name

In order to be able to kill the keepalived state change monitor, we set
its command name to a known constant.

Change-Id: I4e99bfd095bdb1f7959478aa76751c1c24c3c4e2
Partial-Bug: #1795870
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/75/639375/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: WiP/PoC - Router Namespace - Connection Tracker helper
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-03-15 12:39:10.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/conf/agent/l3/config.py', 'neutron/agent/l3/namespaces.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5f969c9df7c753f7a849b0604fdce9208dae8246', 'message': 'WiP/PoC - Router Namespace - Connection Tracker helper

!! This is a PoC only.

In Bionic the nf_conntrack_helper is disabled by default.
This is good security practice, but causes issues for
Ironic CI which need conntrack for TFTP traffic.

The solution seem to be to add firewall rules to the
router namespace to explicitly enable the tftp helper
for the specific port. Example:

 -A PREROUTING -p udp -m udp --dport 69 -j CT --helper tftp

This change adds a config option in l3_agent which allow
specifying a list of dics such as:
  {helper: tftp, proto: udp, port: 69}

The data is then used to apply the firewall rules in the
namespace when it is created.

Change-Id: I88b45799265b8fafcae37f0f0fb0f1106efb1a06
'}]
commit_message:
WiP/PoC - Router Namespace - Connection Tracker helper

!! This is a PoC only.

In Bionic the nf_conntrack_helper is disabled by default.
This is good security practice, but causes issues for
Ironic CI which need conntrack for TFTP traffic.

The solution seem to be to add firewall rules to the
router namespace to explicitly enable the tftp helper
for the specific port. Example:

 -A PREROUTING -p udp -m udp --dport 69 -j CT --helper tftp

This change adds a config option in l3_agent which allow
specifying a list of dics such as:
  {helper: tftp, proto: udp, port: 69}

The data is then used to apply the firewall rules in the
namespace when it is created.

Change-Id: I88b45799265b8fafcae37f0f0fb0f1106efb1a06

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ib04cb5c282eb8e07210ef83676213e41b629f889

commit_message:
rehome policy and cache_utils

Today we have neutron_lib._policy that is 1/2 baked, out of sync and was
never consumed.

This patch updates neutron_lib's policy with the latest from neutron
with the following changes:
- Removed TODO about API attribute typing; we have that IIUC.
- Removed NOTE about _extract() relying on core plugin; we now have the
plugin directory in neutron-lib which IIUC solves this NOTE.
- Removed the 'plugin' kwarg from enforce() and check(). This kwarg is
deprecated and not used by the functions. Now is the time to clean it
up.

In addition neutron.common.cache_utils is rehomed as
neutron_lib.utils.cache. While not used outside neutron today [1], it's
needed by policy and generic in nature.

TEMP TESTING PATCH for neutron consumption:
Depends-On: I300323961a35385e597d803348ca2f877ee55fdd

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron.common%20import%20cache_utils

Change-Id: I788d3c4080fb7ef3f2c1edf1ea3d955f81634732

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_policy import policy _ROLE_ENFORCER = None _ADMIN_CTX_POLICY = 'context_is_admin' _ADVSVC_CTX_POLICY = 'context_is_advsvc' def init(conf=cfg.CONF, policy_file=None): """Initialize the global enforcer if not already initialized. Initialize the global enforcer (and load its rules) if not already initialized; otherwise this is a no-op. :param conf: The configuration to initialize the global enforcer with. Defaults to oslo_config.cfg.CONF. :param policy_file: The policy file to initialize the global enforcer with. :returns: None. """ global _ROLE_ENFORCER if not _ROLE_ENFORCER: _ROLE_ENFORCER = policy.Enforcer(conf, policy_file=policy_file) _ROLE_ENFORCER.load_rules(True) def _check_rule(context, rule): init() # the target is user-self credentials = context.to_policy_values() if rule not in _ROLE_ENFORCER.rules: return False return _ROLE_ENFORCER.enforce(rule, credentials, credentials) def check_is_admin(context): """Verify context has admin rights according to the global policy settings. :param context: The context object. :returns: True if the context has admin rights (as per the global enforcer) and False otherwise. """ return _check_rule(context, _ADMIN_CTX_POLICY) def check_is_advsvc(context): """Verify context has advsvc rights according to global policy settings. :param context: The context object. :returns: True if the context has advsvc rights (as per the global enforcer) and False otherwise. """ return _check_rule(context, _ADVSVC_CTX_POLICY)

commit_message:
rehome securitygroup api def

This patch rehomes the security group API definition. Note that as part
of the rehome a handful of the error messages used on its API validation
and conversion have changed (not the response codes) as a result of
using generic validators/converters rather than 1-off API specific
functions.

A unit test and release note area also included.

Depends-On: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
Change-Id: I9466274a5236645471c1d0aab5c692b4728b8c6c

Allowed values are: %(values)s")

a case the extension may want raise an InUse exception, rather than

As part of adding API definitions to neutron-lib, we want to reuse the
generic validators as much as possible. However as part of this reuse
we shouldn't impact the ability of an API to provide more meaningful
validation error messages that ultimately may ease the API user
experience. Moreover some API's need to customize the HTTP code returned
on validation failure [1].

Today we don't provide a way to customize the generic validator
exceptions/messages, so API's who need more specific error messages
(ex: [1][2]) only have the option to create 1-off validators for
their specific exceptions/messages.

This patch proposes that we allow APIs to customize this exception
class/message by having validators encapsulate their validation
failure data into an object that can then be used by a custom
exception. In addition a basic set of objects are provided to
implement the notion of validation results, options, etc.

Existing style validators that just return a string will still work,
but will be limited in terms of how useful they are for customized
exceptions. To that end this patch updates all lib's validators to use
the new style objects and clarifies that validators should not raise
exceptions unless they are programmatic in nature.

NeutronCoreInputNeeded

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/subnet_service_types.py

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e
"}]
commit_message:
support custom exceptions for api validation

As part of adding API definitions to neutron-lib, we want to reuse the
generic validators as much as possible. However as part of this reuse
we shouldn't impact the ability of an API to provide more meaningful
validation error messages that ultimately may ease the API user
experience. Moreover some API's need to customize the HTTP code returned
on validation failure [1].

Today we don't provide a way to customize the generic validator
exceptions/messages, so API's who need more specific error messages
(ex: [1][2]) only have the option to create 1-off validators for
their specific exceptions/messages.

This patch proposes that we allow APIs to customize this exception
class/message by having validators encapsulate their validation
failure data into an object that can then be used by a custom
exception. In addition a basic set of objects are provided to
implement the notion of validation results, options, etc.

Existing style validators that just return a string will still work,
but will be limited in terms of how useful they are for customized
exceptions. To that end this patch updates all lib's validators to use
the new style objects and clarifies that validators should not raise
exceptions unless they are programmatic in nature.

NeutronCoreInputNeeded

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/securitygroup.py
[2] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/extensions/subnet_service_types.py

Change-Id: I13f24ae7d987b092bb60554ef46e89d882e6782e

added_lines: def test_convert_value_custom_exc_class(self): class _ValidateError(exceptions.InvalidInput): def __init__(self, msg): pass attr_info = { 'key': { 'validate': { 'type:uuid': (None, _ValidateError,) } } } attr_inst = attributes.AttributeInfo(attr_info) self.assertRaises(_ValidateError, self._test_convert_value, attr_inst, {'key': 1}, {'key': 1})

commit_message:
WIP: Rehome libnetfilter_log to neutron-lib

libnetfilter_log is a python binding for netfilter_log API. This library
will be used for firewall group, security group (firewall driver based
iptables) and snat logging to capture packets.

Change-Id: I681f42fb730ad137d47160fc397e03edc1631dfa

commit_message:
WIP: rehome neutron.objects.base and deps

There are a number of consumers today who use neutron.objects.base
[1] and it's conceivable others may need it as OVO is adopted. This
patch rehomes neutron.objects.base and its dependencies and also
includes a test fixture for mocking out the neutron.objects.db.api CRUD
functions.

For a sample consumption patch see:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/620999

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=from%20neutron.objects%20import%20base

Change-Id: I8173c59f26c3a52ea9abf52a58b64a82e1599466

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # TODO(ihrachys): cover the module with functional tests targeting supported # backends from oslo_utils import uuidutils from neutron_lib.db import model_query from neutron_lib import exceptions as n_exc from neutron_lib.objects import utils as obj_utils # Common database operation implementations def _get_filter_query(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): with obj_cls.db_context_reader(context): filters = _kwargs_to_filters(**kwargs) query = model_query.get_collection_query( context, obj_cls.db_model, filters) return query def get_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): return _get_filter_query(obj_cls, context, **kwargs).first() def count(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): return _get_filter_query(obj_cls, context, **kwargs).count() def _kwargs_to_filters(**kwargs): retain_classes = (list, set, obj_utils.StringMatchingFilterObj) return {k: v if isinstance(v, retain_classes) else [v] for k, v in kwargs.items()} def get_objects(obj_cls, context, _pager=None, **kwargs): with obj_cls.db_context_reader(context): filters = _kwargs_to_filters(**kwargs) return model_query.get_collection( context, obj_cls.db_model, dict_func=None, # return all the data filters=filters, **(_pager.to_kwargs(context, obj_cls) if _pager else {})) def create_object(obj_cls, context, values, populate_id=True): with obj_cls.db_context_writer(context): if (populate_id and 'id' not in values and hasattr(obj_cls.db_model, 'id')): values['id'] = uuidutils.generate_uuid() db_obj = obj_cls.db_model(**values) context.session.add(db_obj) return db_obj def _safe_get_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): db_obj = get_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) if db_obj is None: key = ", ".join(['%s=%s' % (key, value) for (key, value) in kwargs.items()]) raise n_exc.ObjectNotFound( id="%s(%s)" % (obj_cls.db_model.__name__, key)) return db_obj def update_object(obj_cls, context, values, **kwargs): with obj_cls.db_context_writer(context): db_obj = _safe_get_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) db_obj.update(values) db_obj.save(session=context.session) return db_obj def delete_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): with obj_cls.db_context_writer(context): db_obj = _safe_get_object(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) context.session.delete(db_obj) def update_objects(obj_cls, context, values, **kwargs): '''Update matching objects, if any. Return number of updated objects. This function does not raise exceptions if nothing matches. :param obj_cls: Object class :param values: values to update in matching objects :param kwargs: multiple filters defined by key=value pairs :return: Number of entries updated ''' with obj_cls.db_context_writer(context): if not values: return count(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) q = _get_filter_query(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) return q.update(values, synchronize_session=False) def delete_objects(obj_cls, context, **kwargs): '''Delete matching objects, if any. Return number of deleted objects. This function does not raise exceptions if nothing matches. :param obj_cls: Object class :param kwargs: multiple filters defined by key=value pairs :return: Number of entries deleted ''' with obj_cls.db_context_writer(context): db_objs = get_objects(obj_cls, context, **kwargs) for db_obj in db_objs: context.session.delete(db_obj) return len(db_objs)

commit_message:
Use unstable_test decorator from neutron-lib

As unstable_test is available in neutron-lib/utils/test.py.
This patch updates the plugin to consume unstable_test from
neutron-lib.

Change-Id: I3aaefa5dc38b5079cdbd98d4ac89df0d03f99eae

commit_message:
Refactor QoS test to make it more reliable

Try to fix some problems and code quality of QoS related tests:
- implement delete_qos_policy method in API base test class and make
  sure it is called to delete QoS policies using the same client used
  to create them (as for other resource type)
- Move QoS floating IP scenario test to QoS test_qos.py test as it uses
  the same base code as the test there (this semplifies and reduces the
  code)
- Fix QoS policies leaks in scenario tests using API base test methdos.
- Implement standalone bash script to test download bandwith with a
  remote server using ncat tool from nmap project (only available on
  advanced images)
- Patch network client to allow creating policies without the optional
  parameter is_default (because it requires qos-default extension)
- Install nmap packace inside Ubuntu guest images

Change-Id: I6eb5e451da2ffb1915c44dcc2354978e56321e4e

commit_message:
debian: add support

This patch adds support for this role to be able to deploy on
Debian Stretch.

Change-Id: Ib5e04011519c67e72a0e64f511bc673527eb4db9
Needed-By: I9a92b73c419a0dc1cca40dacfef75de61a61db94
(cherry picked from commit 0ea86c6967061043b0b39ffcf75a13085d871802)

commit_message:
Add reusable ping command wrapper.

Refactor ping connectivity verification on top of a reusable
ping command wrapper.

Write a new function called ping.get_statistics able of executing
ping command in either a remote host or on local host
and parsing actual ping command output to report ping statistis.

Additional mixin test case mixin class is provided to allow sending
ping message until some specific condition are met:
 - a 'count' of messages is transmitted
 - a 'count' of messages is delivered (transmitted without errors)
 - a 'count' of messages is not delivered (transmitted with errors)
 - a 'count' of messages is received
 - a 'count' of messages is not received (transmitted but not received)

Some new configuration options has been added to tune default
parameters passed to ping command.

Some logic has been added to support CirrOS CLI differences from
regular Unix shells.

This tool allows to make far more precise verifications regarding
ICMP connectivity by reporting more result details than just reporting
success or failure.

Change-Id: I196f3e29eb117dd81ee5721a57ef0b50eef4eca2

commit_message:
Fix support for v1 manifests

v1 manifests store the layer digests in a different way, which the
prepare code has conditional logic to handle, however this is missing
from image copy when discovering source layer digests.

There is also a v1 manifest format error in the image export delete code.

This change fixes both of these issues, which should make it possible
to copy images from quay.io.

Change-Id: I3e6c95beb387dc4b462eb037eeb8cb628016b7e4
Closes-Bug: #1823821

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I915a7c690e127aaf271b3862bbbd63fca582ae2b

Change-Id: I804e5084f74ff4afdd582ece02ff2c833c5f6eb1

commit_message:
Remove message about circular role inferences

While Cycles could be a problem, this code was detercting them even
when there were none.  If a role gets added twice, it was reporting
an error, but that is possible from the case where two distinct prior
add the same implied role.  Just move on quietly.

closes-bug 1803780

Change-Id: I804e5084f74ff4afdd582ece02ff2c833c5f6eb1
(cherry picked from commit 78566e828659b201563e7d07823df30f7b00b0d4)

commit_message:

commit_message:
Make cloudkitty-processor run several workers

This makes the processor run several workers in separate processes by
default, leading to a big performance increase. The maximal number of workers
can be configured. Work items:

* Use cotyledon to spawn several workers.

* Remove eventlet monkey patching and use the "threading" executor for
  messaging in order to avoid conflict with cotyledon internal threads.

Story: 2005423
Task: 30447
Change-Id: I7e2a77cb7d68afb87274fb44fb208306c3b32473
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cloudkitty refs/changes/15/652015/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | The processor is now able to run several parallel workers. By default, one worker is spawned for each available CPU. Workers can be limited through the ``max_workers`` option of the ``orchestrator`` section.

commit_message:
Provide option to disable EMC in puppet-vswitch

This patch disables EMC by setting emc-insert-inv-prob to 0.

Closes-Bug: #1821821
(cherry picked from commit 97eb675dcc41578d1c52aff558533c49c4a925b4)

commit_message:
Allow 'container image prepare' to support drivers

This updates the 'overcloud container image prepare' command
so that it sets the neutron_driver variable correctly. This
allows tripleo-common to detect if OVN or ODL drivers are in
used and prepares the resulting output files for container
images and parameters accordingly.

Previously you could only access this functionality if you
used the new ContainerImagePrepare workflow (requires Mistral).

Change-Id: Icb5b20bfd98a704f3f33f739bc92f77550b52c26
Closes-bug: #1816663
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/89/637989/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I4aaba31efbabd05f95721021a60c8b8049448e77
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-freezer refs/changes/94/645694/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I084f5db7d75ef069cc192bf339e38145f6833f2a

subject: Write hash after compressing horizon static assets
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-10 11:47:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla/commit/94434e005eca7d9f9c3ffa4789a8e65e8ac723ba', 'message': 'Write hash after compressing horizon static assets

If you run the horizon container with a restart policy of never, and the
static asset compression fails, the container fails to start, e.g. (seen
in CI)

++ /usr/bin/manage.py collectstatic --noinput --clear
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/manage.py", line 18, in <module>
      from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
  ImportError: No module named django.core.management

However, with a restart policy of unless-stopped (the default).  the
horizon container will fail the first time but will succeed after a
restart. This is because the settings bundle hash is updated before the
compression is attempted.

To fix this, update the hash after compression completes successfully.

Change-Id: I3f1682ed55e7d45c1e97a1b34c7993aa839f0bb2
Closes-Bug: #1824137

commit_message:
Write hash after compressing horizon static assets

If you run the horizon container with a restart policy of never, and the
static asset compression fails, the container fails to start, e.g. (seen
in CI)

++ /usr/bin/manage.py collectstatic --noinput --clear
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/manage.py", line 18, in <module>
      from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line
  ImportError: No module named django.core.management

However, with a restart policy of unless-stopped (the default).  the
horizon container will fail the first time but will succeed after a
restart. This is because the settings bundle hash is updated before the
compression is attempted.

To fix this, update the hash after compression completes successfully.

Change-Id: I3f1682ed55e7d45c1e97a1b34c7993aa839f0bb2
Closes-Bug: #1824137
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/06/651506/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: HASH_PATH=/var/lib/kolla/.settings.md5sum.txt if [[ ! -f $HASH_PATH ]] || ! settings_bundle | md5sum -c --status $HASH_PATH || [[ $FORCE_GENERATE == yes ]]; then settings_bundle | md5sum > $HASH_PATH
deleted_lines: hash_path=/var/lib/kolla/.settings.md5sum.txt if [[ ! -f $hash_path ]] || ! settings_bundle | md5sum -c --status $hash_path || [[ $FORCE_GENERATE == yes ]]; then settings_bundle | md5sum > $hash_path

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/mimic

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/mimic branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3cd13fd93f639da86d2afd8c8561fecbc5cfdd74

commit_message:
Constraint networkx to <2.3 for Python 2

networkx >=2.3 supports Python 3 only [1]. This patch constraints
networkx to <2.3 for Python 2.

[1] https://networkx.github.io/documentation/stable/news.html#networkx-2-3

Change-Id: Icfc804f40130a613ac78165e487853c47c87e49c

Add Python 3.6 and Python 3.7 jobs

According to 'Tested Runtimes for Train' [1] we need to support
Python 2.7, Python 3.7 and Python 3.6 runtimes.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I449cb6dbad63cca99fbd8a193a59aee326d289f0

added_lines: OpenStack LoadBalancer API and OVN ================================== Introduction ------------ Load balancing is essential for enabling simple or automatic delivery scaling and availability since application delivery scaling and availability must be considered vital features of any cloud Octavia is an open source, operator-scale load balancing solution designed to work with OpenStack. The purpose of this document is to propose a design for how we can use OVN as the backend for OpenStack's LoadBalancer API provided by Octavia. Octavia LoadBalancers Today ---------------------------- A Detailed design analysis of Octavia can be found here: https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/queens/contributor/design/version0.5/component-design.html Currently, Octavia uses the in-built Amphorae driver to fulfill the Loadbalancing requests in Openstack. Amphoare can be a Virtual machine, container, dedicated hardware, appliance or device that actually performs the task of load balancing in the Octavia system. More specifically, an amphora takes requests from clients on the front-end and distributes these to back-end systems. Amphorae communicate with their controllers over the LB Network through a driver interface on the controller. The issue here is that Amphorae needs a placeholder, for eg a separate VM/Container etc to be deployed so that it can handle the LB requests. Along with this, it also needs a separate network( termed as lb-mgmt-network ) which handles all Amphorae requests. Amphorae has the capability to handle L4(TCP/UDP) as well as L7(HTTP) LoadBalancer requests. It also has the capability of being monitored and thus helps in fixing if something is broken. Octavia with OVN ----------------------------- OVN currently doesnt support L7 protocols, but it does support L4 protocols. Also, currently it does not have any facility to be monitored. However, it does not need any extra hadrware/VM/Container to be deployed, which is a major positive point when compared with Amphorae. Also, it does not require any special network to handle the LB requests as they are taken care by OpenFlows directly. Also, though OVN does not have support for TLS, it is in the works and once implemented can be integrated with Octavia This following section details about how OVN can be used as an Octavia driver. Overview of Proposed Approach ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The OVN Driver for Octavia runs under the scope of o-api. Octavia API receives and forwards calls to the OVN Driver. As mentioned above, following actions are not supported by OVN Driver: - Creating a LoadBalancer/Listener/Pool with L7 Protocol support - Creating HealthMonitors **Step 1** - Creating a LoadBalancer Octavia API recieves and issues a LoadBalancer creation request on a network to the OVN Provider driver. OVN driver creates a LoadBalancer in the OVN NorthBound DB and asynchronously updates the Octavia Database with the status response. A VIP port is created in Neutron when the LoadBalancer creation is complete. The VIP information however is not updated in the NorthBound DB until the Members are not associated with the LoadBalancer's Pool. **Step 2** - Creating LoadBalancer entities( Pools, Listeners, Members) Once a LoadBalancer is created by OVN in its NorthBound DB, Users can now create Pools, Listeners and Members associated with the LoadBalancer using the Octavia API. With the creation of each entity the LoadBalancer's external_ids column in the NorthBound DB would be updated and corresponding Logical and Openflows would be added for handling them. **Step 3** - LoadBalancer request processing When a user sends a request to the VIP IP address, the Logical Flow in OVN's SouthBound DB is verified. Once the correspoinding Logical Flow is found in the DB, the packet is forwarded using OVN's tunnelling mechanism from the VIP to any one of the members. Member selection is based on the Pool's LoadBalancing Algorithm. Once the appropriate Member is selected by Octavia, the corresponding flow is used to direct the traffic from the VIP to the associated Member. OVN LoadBalancer Driver Logic ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * On startup: * Do a full sync. * Open and maintain a connection to the OVN Northbound database (using the ovsdbapp library). On first connection, and anytime a reconnect happens: * Do a full sync. * Register a callback when a new interface is added to a router or deleted from a router. * When a new LoadBalancer L1 is created, create a Row in OVN's *load_balancer* table, and update its entries for Name and Network References. If the network on which the LoadBalancer is created is associated with a Router, say R1, then add the router reference to the LoadBalancer and associate the LoadBalancer to the router. For all networks which have an interface on the router R1, associate the LoadBalancer L1 with all the networks. This is required so that Logical Flows for inter-network communication while using the LoadBalancer L1 is possible. Also, during this time, a new port is created via Neutron which acts as a VIP Port. The information of this new port is not visible on the OVN's NorthBound DB till a member is not added to the LoadBalancer. * If a new network interface is added to the router R1 described above, all the Loadbalancers on that network are associated with the Router R1 and all the LoadBalancers on the Router are associated with the new network. * If a network interface is removed from the router R1, then all the LoadBalancers which have been solely created on that Network(identified using the *ls_ref* attribute in the LoadBalancer's *external_ids*) are removed from the Router. Similarly those loadbalancers which are associated with the network but not actually created on that network are removed from the network. * LoadBalancer can either be torn-down with all its children entities using the *cascade* option, or the individual members/pools/listeners can be deleted. When the LoadBalancer is deleted, all its references and associations from all networks and routers are removed. This might change in the future once the association of LoadBalancers with Networks/Routers are changed to *weak* from *strong* [3]. Also the VIP port is deleted when the LoadBalancer is deleted. Other References ---------------- [1] Octavia API: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/ [2] Octavia Glossary: https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/queens/reference/glossary.html [3] https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/612f80fa8ebf88dad2e204364c6c02b451dca36c

When deploying osd, if the user does not use the extra block
partition, the kolla will automatically partition the disk and then
clean up the data on the disk partition. Sometimes the disk partition
will not be updated, there will be an error not finding the partition.

This commit fixes the problem.

Change-Id: I14708f38614dcb75268c2f460ae3d921748c2d10
Closes-bug: #1824787
'}]
commit_message:
Fix the problem of osd initialization failed

When deploying osd, if the user does not use the extra block
partition, the kolla will automatically partition the disk and then
clean up the data on the disk partition. Sometimes the disk partition
will not be updated, there will be an error not finding the partition.

This commit fixes the problem.

Change-Id: I14708f38614dcb75268c2f460ae3d921748c2d10
Closes-bug: #1824787
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/12/652612/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I28edbeb718f162fbee01b9fbd30b214bc9aab3f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-aodh refs/changes/65/645665/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Trim whitespace in multi-line env descriptions

Indenting blank description lines just creates unnecessary trailing
whitespace in the output file.  Skip the indentation in this case.

Change-Id: Ib0fbd26b489f6d9cf262c1186d3b3e604d4c0c67

subject: Correct error catching while in "--check" mode
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-15 11:42:33.000000000', 'files': ['docker/services/haproxy.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/5435f13daa8d8a8bc97e552cb57699c589de6c0a', 'message': 'Correct error catching while in "--check" mode

When we're in "--check" mode with Ansible, the variable is defined,
but its content doesn't match the one we might get when actually applying
the run.
The right way to detect that is to check if the variable is changed.

In "--check", it is not changed, meaning we can't get the "rc" attribute.

I5851dc7820fdcc4f5790980d94b81622ce3b0c8d didn't do the right check, and
does not improve the situation.

Change-Id: I77c655addd0fe01948584fb43ba24d5b24ff330e
Closes-Bug: #1823841
(cherry picked from commit cb9497d76b22aaa8ad38c07183fbc551dbda3acf)
'}]
commit_message:
Correct error catching while in "--check" mode

When we're in "--check" mode with Ansible, the variable is defined,
but its content doesn't match the one we might get when actually applying
the run.
The right way to detect that is to check if the variable is changed.

In "--check", it is not changed, meaning we can't get the "rc" attribute.

I5851dc7820fdcc4f5790980d94b81622ce3b0c8d didn't do the right check, and
does not improve the situation.

Change-Id: I77c655addd0fe01948584fb43ba24d5b24ff330e
Closes-Bug: #1823841
(cherry picked from commit cb9497d76b22aaa8ad38c07183fbc551dbda3acf)

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.common import waiters from tempest import config from tempest.lib.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import decorators from cinder_tempest_plugin.api.volume import base CONF = config.CONF class VolumeRetypeTest(base.BaseVolumeTest): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(VolumeRetypeTest, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.volume_feature_enabled.backup: raise cls.skipException("Cinder backup feature disabled") @decorators.idempotent_id('07af8f6d-80af-44c9-a5dc-c8427b1b62e6') @utils.services('compute') def test_retype_and_attached_volume(self): """Test retype volume and then attempt to attach the volume to an instance. create using force flag. """ # create volume and retype volume = self.create_volume(volume_type=self.src_vol_type['name']) self.addCleanup(self.delete_volume, self.volumes_client, volume['id']) self._retype_volume(volume, migration_policy='on-demand') # Create a server server = self.create_server() # Attach volume to instance self.attach_volume(server['id'], volume['id'])

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: I7d3fab02f1ae89aa6c675ce19a9858a1729323c1

commit_message:
Revert "readOnlyRootFilesystem: true for openvswitch chart"

I believe when we have set the readOnly flag at pod without HTK functionality the changes were not reflected. That is why it passed the gate.

Later with HTK functionality the gates never passed and I have tested that in various ways and finally I had to unset the readOnly flag

This reverts commit 598040bea05737ea1ee2460ba8675ed7c061e63a.

Change-Id: Icf8d3cc60045926ab60b9735ee1e8202c15df9d5

commit_message:
Use ISO8601 format for timestamp fields

Most OpenStack services use format ISO8601 for timestamp fields
like 'created_at' or 'updated_at'. This commit makes Zun adopt
this convention.

Change-Id: I900b2f106d2ea0c044140077dfda39e1402a09ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/71/652371/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetimefrom zun.common import utils if isinstance(value, datetime.datetime): yield (key, utils.strtime(value)) else: yield (key, value) if isinstance(value, datetime.datetime): yield (key, utils.strtime(value)) else: if key == 'traceback' and not show_traceback: # By default, non-admins are not allowed to see traceback # details. yield (key, None) else: yield (key, value)
deleted_lines: yield (key, value) if key == 'traceback' and not show_traceback: # By default, non-admins are not allowed to see traceback details. yield (key, None) else: yield (key, value)

commit_message:
Refactor the code of API controller/view

Extract view out of controllers: ContainerAction, ContainerActionEvent,
and Service. This makes improve the modularity and consistency of
the code.

Change-Id: I34ce08f2e1a93fbb9c15055f1e31b17454531b5c

commit_message:
Set Standalone's br-ctlplane MTU

Set the br-ctlplane MTU to the InterfaceLocalMtu value. This is
required when multiple Standalone nodes are used in a split-stack
deployment.

Closes-Bug: #1823993
Change-Id: I84a35d529ee67e939db1cdadd103f88295e41e8f

commit_message:
Skip populating container's state on tasks

If there is a task acting on this container, skip syncing its
state on _populate_container_state to avoid conflicts.

Change-Id: I8b1bcc6c0399b163e26619db893b118f93d6ba9a

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

commit_message:
Release cinderlib 0.9.0

This commit releases cinderlib 0.9.0 as agreed in the Cinder team
meeting to reflect it is a Tech Preview release, but almost ready for
production.

We release cinderlib as an independent project in this cycle, but it
will be moved to the cycle-trailing release cycle on Train, which fits
nicely with its dependency on the Cinder project.  After all cinderlib
treats Cinder as a mere driver package.

Change-Id: Idc37f4c66f9eb38126bafc49326427db67713503

subject: Change sample id from int to BigInt
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-02-28 23:21:54.000000000', 'files': ['ceilometer/storage/sqlalchemy/migrate_repo/versions/046_sample_id_to_bigint.py', 'ceilometer/storage/sqlalchemy/models.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer/commit/6ea3df4d86a058dfc4aff4f9f01ff399a07228ab', 'message': 'Change sample id from int to BigInt

For long running users of Ceilometer with heavy sample loads,
the index for samples can run out of numbers.  The int type only
allows over 2 billion samples to be loaded.  To allow a user
with database backed sample storage (postgres or mysql) to continue
to operate, we need to up the data type to BigInteger.

Change-Id: I9ed1d69a05efd47368497674ffe68b43c8dc1074
'}]
commit_message:
Change sample id from int to BigInt

For long running users of Ceilometer with heavy sample loads,
the index for samples can run out of numbers.  The int type only
allows over 2 billion samples to be loaded.  To allow a user
with database backed sample storage (postgres or mysql) to continue
to operate, we need to up the data type to BigInteger.

Change-Id: I9ed1d69a05efd47368497674ffe68b43c8dc1074
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/24/640224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

_list_tokens_for_consumer should use sql read sessions

"sql.session_for_write"

subject: Refactoring of Enforcer class
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-22 12:27:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.policy/commit/9cb2989764d5abc9a2e50b57942043abac2a57e6', 'message': "Allow policy file to not exist

Now that policy rules can be registered in code there is a desire to run
projects without a policy file. However oslo.policy assumed a policy
file would exist and would raise an error if it could not be found. This
was fixed by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/341732/

These changes make Enforcer logic more simple.
And Enforcer can be extendend or improved without adding
more flags.
Everything related to file was moved to FileRulesCache class.
It is easy to read code or debug.
This refactoring shouldn't break anything in projects
because Enforcer API was not changed.

Change-Id: Iaddb1f096a4a085f08b83e3c86c3910b7e26f40a
Closes-Bug: #1603329

commit_message:
Refactoring of Enforcer class

Now that policy rules can be registered in code there is a desire to run
projects without a policy file. However oslo.policy assumed a policy
file would exist and would raise an error if it could not be found. This
was fixed by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/341732/

After this fix it became noticible that Enforcer class
not only enforces but also stores rules. And this should be changed.
Enforcing and storing shoud be separated.

These changes make Enforcer logic more simple.
And Enforcer can be extendend or improved without adding
more flags.
Everything related to file was moved to FileRulesCache class.
It is easy to read code or debug.
This refactoring shouldn't break anything in projects
because Enforcer API was not changed.

Change-Id: Iaddb1f096a4a085f08b83e3c86c3910b7e26f40a
Closes-Bug: #1603329

commit_message:
Fix tls-proxy issues with the devstack plugin

Enabling tls-proxy allows devstack to
set up a tls proxy server that front-ends
interactions with the manila-api and
terminates tls connections.

Also enable tls-proxy in dummy and lvm
jobs. The dummy driver job is configured
to run the in-built wsgi server, the lvm
job is configured to use mod-wsgi.

Closes-Bug: #1816836
Change-Id: I48b0ccc082604d78242ba61bee94a45efeb2467b
(cherry picked from commit 8f1c7dc91fb1e00784f6228526d95f4434ba8a01)
(cherry picked from commit edc60f76c2818351f8a6d1090a5549970b1891cc)

commit_message:
Correct error catching while in "--check" mode

When we're in "--check" mode with Ansible, the variable is defined,
but its content doesn't match the one we might get when actually applying
the run.
The right way to detect that is to check if the variable is changed.

In "--check", it is not changed, meaning we can't get the "rc" attribute.

I5851dc7820fdcc4f5790980d94b81622ce3b0c8d didn't do the right check, and
does not improve the situation.

Change-Id: I77c655addd0fe01948584fb43ba24d5b24ff330e
Related-Bug: #1823841

commit_message:
Wire in parameters.convert_docker_params

This adds a call to parameters.convert_docker_params
to our template processing function so that Overcloud
deploys will have Docker* parameters converted to
the new varients transparently.

Change-Id: I7d62a3424ccb7b01dc101329018ebda896ea8ff3

commit_message:
Check policy_complete on keystone request

As a protection against policy mistakes as we begin a refactor add a
flag to each request keystone receives that indicates whether or not a
policy enforcement check has been completed for that request. Requests
that don't require policy enforcement will simply accept the flag.

Any request that tries to return a success response that has not had
policy enforced on it should return a 500 error as this is a server side
bug as somehow a request has managed to skip our RBAC protection.

Change-Id: Ie70fe823fd3c03235977a212bd8ab4dca31ed68d
